summary: I was discussing Sansa with a show-only fan who insisted that Sansa was a really bad sister. I remember her saying that to Jon,...
question: I was discussing Sansa with a show-only fan who insisted that Sansa was a really bad sister. I remember her saying that to Jon, but I don't recall anything like that in the books, aside from her precisely stating "half-brother", and I'd say her & Arya was just typical sister stuff, given how they think about each other, and maybe 50% Arya's fault (being spunky is not an excuse to wing an orange at your sister). Was her portrayal worse on GoT?
answer:
Mixed, I’d say, but also mostly the result of the show’s recent lousy plotting  and longer-term issues depicting Sansa’s interiority rather than serious intention to depict Sansa as a sub-par sibling.

I mean, she really was a rubbish sibling in s6. Her lies to Jon were a big fucking deal. She denied him knowledge of a whole army ready to assist them, which absolutely hamstrung their efforts to gain more allies and in no small way contributed to the…interesting…tactical situation in 6.09. And yet from the start of 6.09, where Sansa is suddenly and mysteriously refusing to participate in discussions she’d been welcome and able to contribute to all season long, apparently her lies are because Jon didn’t make the effort to include her. This is what I mean by bad writing. There was no good reason for her actions, in-universe or out, and yet it’s the canon we have to work with.

She was also pretty craptacular in 7.01, responding to a reasonable “don’t criticise me in public” request with “YOU’RE JUST LIKE JOFFREY!” Seriously, what the hell.

Then she turned on a dime and became actually a damn good sister, holding the fort when Jon was neglecting it. And yet somehow, if Arya was to be believed, Sansa was actually being a bad sister there and in the past? I dunno. Her worst crime following Jon’s departure seemed to me to be taking a bit too long to say “thanks but no thanks” when the Northern lords offered to crown her. Unless you count having pretty handwriting. That scheming witch. How dare she.

If we’re talking backstory, though, we have precious little on show!Sansa’s relationships with her siblings. The show!Starks hardly talk about each other. Sansa’s assertion that she was a horrible sister back then is one of the more detailed descriptions we have of pre-1.01 interactions between the Stark siblings. We may just have to take her word for it.

title: Trust Each Other - Part 2
body:
As I brought up in my previous post,  a lot of the time when people talk about Jon and Sansa’s dynamic on the show, they don’t really reflect on why that “tension” exists as much or what it’s really about. The characters keep shifting between arguing and bickering to letting down their guard for a bit and being vulnerable around each other. But there’s always something left unsaid. Something that isn’t acknowledged. This unlabelled “something” is a number of issues related to their individual journeys, the perception of them, but also, as I noted in Part 1, it comes down to romantic framing of that tension as well using cinematic devices that goes far beyond actors’ chemistry.

The way this dynamic is framed narratively, the personal is political and the political is personal. The ‘otherness’ that doesn’t exist in Jon and Arya’s dynamic exists in Jon and Sansa’s.  It’s a very confusing dynamic to a person who wants to establish them as “complete enemies” or just “sibling rivalry” (as they don’t know they’re cousins) because they never completely settle into that. Their biggest theme being ‘trust each other’, not because they do completely, but because they want to and struggle to be able to. In a way, it all comes back to the 7x01 script note “They skirt around the true tension between them; all is subtext.”

“Maybe it’s the late second act complication that gives way to ~~~love~~~~~.( I am amused by how the show seems to vacillate wildly between [Jon and Sansa] being secretly in love and secretly enemies.)” - Todd VanDerWerff in his responses to a comment on his 6x10 review

Although I had said last time that I will be getting into discussing the characters’ individual after providing the context of cinematic framing, I will be stalling that for another post it seems. This post elaborates on the way Jon and Sansa are shot creates both visual romantic tension, but also narrative tension, and how that plays a role in storytelling.

The Tension between the Familiar and the Unfamiliar 

As you see from Todd VanDerWerff’s quote above, he describes them with two polar opposites, secretly in love and secretly enemies, that it oscillates “wildly” between. It’s a tension of opposites. “Tuesdays with Morrie” seems relevant to quote here. As I go through this series while delving into more character motivations in scenes, this quote will become more relevant to explain why Jon and Sansa react the way they do.

“The tension of opposites: Life is a series of pulls back and forth. You want to do one thing, but you are bound to do something else. Something hurts you, yet you know it shouldn’t. You take certain things for granted, even when you know you should never take anything for granted. A tension of opposites, like a pull on a rubber band. And most of us live somewhere in the middle.” - Tuesdays with Morrie by Mitch Albom

Because of these two polar opposite descriptors “secretly in love” and “secretly enemies”, it creates a push and pull to their dynamic, which doesn’t allow it to settle into a stable sibling-like dynamic that they want to settle into, despite never having it. It creates the feeling of the trope of “Will They or Won’t They?” where even their arguments feel like Belligerent Sexual Tension or Like An Old Married Couple because of the way they are shot.

“Sansa and Jon proceed to get into a very old-married-couple fight.” - Rachel Handler, MTV 6x09 review

“With all their bickering, one almost wonders if [Jon and Sansa] are a few episodes away from getting down together.” - Bennett Madison, Vanity Fair episode 7x01 review

“So Jon and Sansa…they’re like cousins right? […] I think they’re going to end up together” “Maybe I’m just crazy but I’m feeling vibes and that makes me feel better because I felt like they were pushing that” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x01 Podcast

“I said this last episode. They’re creating this weird tension between Jon and Sansa and we know he’s not her brother” “Yeah they’re cousins” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x02 podcast

But it does go a lot deeper than that because it comes down to the underlying emotions and unfamiliarity between these characters despite growing up in Winterfell together. It’s more “known” to them to not connect with each other or trust each other (and definitely not be attracted to each other). So a lot of the fighting personal insecurities aside, is about wanting a sense of going back to what they know because the entire situation feels too strange. To understand the root of this tension between Jon and Sansa, one has to go back to the very first scene of them that we see on screen. Their reunion.

“The characters had not seen each other for a number of years (six seasons) and so what we discussed was that it should seem almost dream like to them, and that there would be some tentativeness to their actions. It was about stringing along the anticipation of the reunion as long as possible to create the feeling of longing and so that the moment they hugged would feel earned and satisfying.” - Sackheim, Reddit Q&A

Of the reunions so far, it was the most emotionally rewarding despite being the most distant growing up and despite the underlying conflict between them that comes up afterward. The “almost dream-like” effect that Sackheim talks about shows in their reunion more than others. As Jon and Sansa still upon seeing each other, and hold eyes only on each other as Jon slowly makes his way to her and stands in front of her, still staring, unable to believe she is there. As Bran has been subsumed under the Three Eyed Raven, he is emotionally absent and anyway, Sansa breaks her disbelief with Bran much faster than she did with Jon in episode 6x04. Later, Arya comes to Winterfell with expectations of seeing Jon, who she was closest to, and finds Sansa, who she had a strained relationship, instead. Arya is met with a bit of disappointment because she had expectations. Thus, it is a bit - if not completely - underwhelming because it’s visible that it is underwhelming to Arya.

“The idea that after all Jon and Sansa have been through as characters, they’re finally able to put a foot back on solid ground in terms of family and with whom that runs deeper than any other bond. It was a big moment for them and for us to see it” “And to knowing where two of them are going to go with their relationship that never really meant that much before but now means so much more because at this point, they’re all that they have.” - D&D, Inside the Episode

Jon and Sansa, on the other hand, because of never being close and being the first of the pack to reunite, didn’t have any such high expectations. After the journeys they went through, anything from each other felt like an oasis in a desert. They fall into a strange ease and comfort, a quiet solace with moments of banter, but they also resist it. Sackheim brings up two conflicting emotions that their reunion was meant to capture: joy and fear, where the fear is overpowering and holds them back.

“The only note I gave them during the scene was, “Hold yourself back. As much as it’s joyous to see each other, you’re equally as scared. You don’t know what to expect.” The operative word was fear. Fear of the unknown. In a way, it added to the emotional resonance of the scene” - David Sackheim, director of 6x04 on Jon and Sansa’s reunion

Sackheim’s emphasis on that “tentativeness” and “fear of the unknown” in the scene is what builds tension in that scene before offering catharsis. While I do think that Jon and Arya’s reunion may still capture that “almost dream-like” effect, because of their close relationship growing up, there would be no fear. Currently where the story left off, they are aware of each other’s survival and hope to reunite at Winterfell so watching it happen might bring on the waterworks but so would it bring on pure unadulterated joy because they’ve probably imagined this a number of times. There would be familiarity and complete unfaltering trust in Jon and Arya’s dynamic. On the other hand, as glad as Jon and Sansa are to find one another, their mutual “fear of the unknown” prevents them from ever completely falling into a sibling dynamic, even when they try to build bridges. In a way because of its two conflicting feelings of joy and fear, it encompasses Faulkner’s “conflict in the human heart”, that Martin is inspired by. This fear isn’t simply because of Cat’s influence on Sansa growing up, but also because of what is happening between them as they feel like almost strangers getting to know one another.

What really grips me about Sackheim’s phrase “Fear of the unknown” on a psychological level for these two characters is that it reminds me the the concept of Unheimlich that Freud talks about in his essay “The Uncanny”. I know this might start appearing a bit too wordy, but bear with me. This is only a minute section in a larger series of posts. Just to clarify I don’t think the creators in question actually read the essay, but I think it does offer some insight within the field of aesthetics, that most people seem to innately understand without reflecting on the “why”. The themes of familiarity and unfamiliarity are a part of a huge body of literature, whether in a social, political or psychological sense.

As a disclaimer, I think Freud’s theories are heavily criticisable, especially on a scientific level and this is perhaps, one of the only essays that I think has worth because it’s more literary and taps into themes explored in fiction. In his essay, Freud talks about the closest explanation “uncanny” comes from the German word unheimlich, which is the opposite of the word heimlich that means “homely” or familiar. So unheimlich means “unhomely” and unfamiliar. He also writes that fear is a fundamental part of the “uncanny”. Many interpret this as “uncanny” or unheimlich to mean fear of the unfamiliar. That is how I felt Sackheim’s quote connects. Of course, it’s a lot more complicated than that because Jon and Sansa aren’t exactly strangers because they grew up in the same vicinity in Winterfell, but they were hardly involved in each other’s lives. They were part of an extended group of Starks but on the two polar opposite sides of the spectrum. Incidentally, Freud argues that the definition of the “uncanny” or unheimlich is not so concrete.

“In general we are reminded that the word ‘heimlich’ is not unambiguous, but belongs to two sets of ideas, which, without being contradictory, are yet very different: on the one hand it means what is familiar and agreeable, and on the other, what is concealed and kept out of sight. ‘Unheimlich’ is customarily used, we are told, as the contrary only of the first signification of ‘heimlich’, and not of the second. Sanders tells us nothing concerning a possible genetic connection between these two meanings of heimlich. On the other hand, we notice that Schelling says something which throws quite a new light on the concept of the Unheimlich, for which we were certainly not prepared. According to him, everything is unheimlich that ought to have remained secret and hidden but has come to light.” - “The Uncanny (1919), Freud

So essentially, the second understanding of “unheimlich” means something familiar and hidden that is revealed. In the case of the story in question, this concept is explored through Jon and Sansa’s inappropriate feelings for one another thinking of each other as half-siblings and his actual parentage that is hidden from them and the rest of the world. In a literary manner, the presence of these inappropriate attraction is them somewhere deep down knowing Jon is “not a Stark”, i.e. he isn’t Ned’s son, and scratching on the concealed truth. There is a certain irony to the idea that Jon wonders why he is having these inappropriate Targaryen-like incestuous feelings and the truth being that he is in fact Targaryen. In literature, authors can explore a number of things that may not work in real life, like this gut feeling of infringing on some prohibited territory that would reveal the lie around which Jon’s life has been wrapped around.

The fact that the show revealed Jon’s parentage in the same episode where it seemed to frame his scenes with Sansa quite romantically, adds to this reading. The characters are unaware of it, but as viewers there is some, if not complete, relief offered for noticing this odd framing of two characters belonging to the House with a reputation of being too honourable. One may brush this off because Jon and Dany’s relationship in season 7. But this piece of information is heavily implied a whole season before they actually meet and commit accidental incest, which is another literary trope that follows punishment. There is also a kind of irony in the fact that Jon distances himself from Sansa to avoid committing incest, and because of his lack of knowledge on his parentage commits it anyway. In the larger scheme of things, his feelings for Sansa as a cousin would not be considered wrong in Westeros and many a match were made around cousin marriages.

Of course, the show doesn’t explicitly acknowledge it and the crew remains silent on it even more than the cast, which is unsure at best and otherwise describing this tension as “sibling rivalry”. But as I pointed out in my last post, it’s not about the actors’ chemistry. It’s about their cinematic framing that uses visual romantic subtext, the methodology of which trinuviel and bitchcakegreen have talked about in their posts. It requires a large number of people involved to actually deliver this result so a lot of people, including directors of completely different episodes, were required to maintain this consistency. It’s not only shippers who noted this, but a number of reviewers who didn’t exactly want it to happen and were confused by the “framing” and the “way it was shot”.

“I definitely think they’re building some sort of romantic something between the two, and I’m not sure where any of it is supposed to be headed. But it’s definitely strange! (In particular, they seem to be deliberately framing the two as roughly analogous to Ned and Cat.)” - Todd VanDerWerff in response to his comments on his 6x10 review.

The show seems to make them visually nod to a number of positive romantic dynamics like Ned/Cat, Jaime/Brienne, Sam/Gilly, Robb/Talisa, and even a bit of Greyworm/Missandei. Many of these are noted by reviewers. That’s a lot of romantic dynamics to visually echo if you want this relationship to be read as platonic. If that wasn’t enough, one of the oddest things is that in the last episode where Jon and Sansa shared scenes together, the show nodded to not only Ned’s choke-hold of Littlefinger over Cat in season 1, but also Jaime and Brienne’s season 6 goodbye. Mark Mylod who was the director episode 7x02, also directed episode 6x08, where Jaime and Brienne had their goodbye scene. That’s alluding to two romantic dynamics in two back-to-back scenes, while the characters’ intentions behind certain actions are left ambiguous. It’s subtle, like the quiet chemistry involved in couples framed to be in the initial stages of courtship in period dramas. There is teasing banter and shows of affection, but there is also a hesitation and holding back in these moments apart from those that involve arguments. 

This continues with Jon’s odd reactions to Sansa’s “suitors” mentioning her, the goodbye scene at Dragonstone where Jorah looks back at Dany while Jon doesn’t, their confusing titles as Jon is KITN but not Lord of Winterfell as Sansa is Lady (and acting Lord) of Winterfell because of her claim, the use of the Lord’s chambers as a narrative device, and people questioning the nature of Sansa’s feelings towards Jon assuming her hesitation to be about power rather than something else. Somehow, because of the other dynamics coming into the fold while Jon and Sansa are distanced, their moments of connection are spelt out even more. Jon and Sansa argued and kept things from each other, but ultimately they still had conversations where they cleared the air and also let down their guard a little. They allowed themselves a few moments of vulnerability and offering each other validation despite their disagreements. This did not happen with Sansa and Arya, who had more of a relationship growing up than Jon and Sansa.  

A number of people’s reactions come with the descriptors “strange” and “weird” and a hesitation to completely believe. The fact that it comes off strange may be deliberate as the characters never really act on anything or acknowledge this romantic tension and the audience is left hanging. It leaves one with a feeling of unease because one doesn’t know what to expect and if it is truly happening. It’s kind of a continuation of Sackheim’s “stringing along the anticipation […] as long as possible to create a feeling of longing” which is built around that tentativeness of their actions. Even when it is pushed to the background. Four directors after Sackheim carry on this tension, where they share scenes (and more if you count related scenes). There is a “je ne sais quoi”, an indefinable, intrinsic feeling to it all. The trained viewer, who has consumed a lot of visual-audio content, can see it - even if they don’t want to - because of internalising the language of film. Even the argument about it as having no basis in books is very contestable. 

The result is that as much as the characters do not know what to expect, the audience doesn’t either. So, it is easier to fall into the alternative explanation that the narrative acknowledges in the text even when it doesn’t answer everything about the subtext. Certain actions may be dismissed as a coincidence, but it starts feeling more strange when the occurences keep building and even make narrative (and political) sense. Therefore, not only are the characters made to undergo this “uncanny” experience so is the audience made to, even when they know the truth about Jon’s parentage and how it could change everything that one assumed about the story before. It crosses the boundary of shipping this dynamic to become about people deep down needing to know if they were right about what the show was telling them via framing. It’s the same kind of relief that people who thought episode 6x10 undoubtedly framed them romantically felt after Jon’s parentage reveal later in the episode. 

I cannot know the ending of the story, of course, but I’ve said multiple times that season 7 didn’t end possibilities. Rather made it more of an inevitable political requirement should he survive. Politics, as loosely as D&D follow it, is at the crux of the story. Everything stands because of the end goal is headed. As much as I’d like to go into scene break-downs already, because Jon and Dany have occurred in the story, it is difficult to avoid discussing their very own framing. In the next post, I will talk about the visual juxtaposition of Jon/Dany and Jon/Sansa within the same season as they share two directors for different episodes.

(to be continued…)

The Tension between the Familiar and the Unfamiliar

It’s a tension of opposites. “Tuesdays with Morrie” seems relevant to quote here. As I go through this series while delving into more character motivations in scenes, this quote will become more relevant to explain why Jon and Sansa react the way they do.

[[MORE]]

Because of these two polar opposite descriptors “secretly in love” and “secretly enemies”, it creates a push and pull to their dynamic, which doesn’t allow it to settle into a stable sibling-like dynamic that they want to settle into, despite never having it. It creates the feeling of the trope of “Will They or Won’t They?” where even their arguments feel like Belligerent Sexual Tension or Like An Old Married Couple because of the way they are shot.

“Sansa and Jon proceed to get into a very old-married-couple fight.” - Rachel Handler, MTV 6x09 review

“With all their bickering, one almost wonders if [Jon and Sansa] are a few episodes away from getting down together.” - Bennett Madison, Vanity Fair episode 7x01 review

“So Jon and Sansa…they’re like cousins right? […] I think they’re going to end up together” “Maybe I’m just crazy but I’m feeling vibes and that makes me feel better because I felt like they were pushing that” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x01 Podcast

“I said this last episode. They’re creating this weird tension between Jon and Sansa and we know he’s not her brother” “Yeah they’re cousins” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x02 podcast

But it does go a lot deeper than that because it comes down to the underlying emotions and unfamiliarity between these characters despite growing up in Winterfell together. It’s more “known” to them to not connect with each other or trust each other (and definitely not be attracted to each other). So a lot of the fighting personal insecurities aside, is about wanting a sense of going back to what they know because the entire situation feels too strange. To understand the root of this tension between Jon and Sansa, one has to go back to the very first scene of them that we see on screen. Their reunion.

“The characters had not seen each other for a number of years (six seasons) and so what we discussed was that it should seem almost dream like to them, and that there would be some tentativeness to their actions. It was about stringing along the anticipation of the reunion as long as possible to create the feeling of longing and so that the moment they hugged would feel earned and satisfying.” - Sackheim, Reddit Q&A

Of the reunions so far, it was the most emotionally rewarding despite being the most distant growing up and despite the underlying conflict between them that comes up afterward. The “almost dream-like” effect that Sackheim talks about shows in their reunion more than others. As Jon and Sansa still upon seeing each other, and hold eyes only on each other as Jon slowly makes his way to her and stands in front of her, still staring, unable to believe she is there. As Bran has been subsumed under the Three Eyed Raven, he is emotionally absent and anyway, Sansa breaks her disbelief with Bran much faster than she did with Jon in episode 6x04. Later, Arya comes to Winterfell with expectations of seeing Jon, who she was closest to, and finds Sansa, who she had a strained relationship, instead. Arya is met with a bit of disappointment because she had expectations. Thus, it is a bit - if not completely - underwhelming because it’s visible that it is underwhelming to Arya.

“The idea that after all Jon and Sansa have been through as characters, they’re finally able to put a foot back on solid ground in terms of family and with whom that runs deeper than any other bond. It was a big moment for them and for us to see it” “And to knowing where two of them are going to go with their relationship that never really meant that much before but now means so much more because at this point, they’re all that they have.” - D&D, Inside the Episode

Jon and Sansa, on the other hand, because of never being close and being the first of the pack to reunite, didn’t have any such high expectations. After the journeys they went through, anything from each other felt like an oasis in a desert. They fall into a strange ease and comfort, a quiet solace with moments of banter, but they also resist it. Sackheim brings up two conflicting emotions that their reunion was meant to capture: joy and fear, where the fear is overpowering and holds them back.

“The only note I gave them during the scene was, “Hold yourself back. As much as it’s joyous to see each other, you’re equally as scared. You don’t know what to expect.” The operative word was fear. Fear of the unknown. In a way, it added to the emotional resonance of the scene” - David Sackheim, director of 6x04 on Jon and Sansa’s reunion

Sackheim’s emphasis on that “tentativeness” and “fear of the unknown” in the scene is what builds tension in that scene before offering catharsis. While I do think that Jon and Arya’s reunion may still capture that “almost dream-like” effect, because of their close relationship growing up, there would be no fear. Currently where the story left off, they are aware of each other’s survival and hope to reunite at Winterfell so watching it happen might bring on the waterworks but so would it bring on pure unadulterated joy because they’ve probably imagined this a number of times. There would be familiarity and complete unfaltering trust in Jon and Arya’s dynamic. On the other hand, as glad as Jon and Sansa are to find one another, their mutual “fear of the unknown” prevents them from ever completely falling into a sibling dynamic, even when they try to build bridges. In a way because of its two conflicting feelings of joy and fear, it encompasses Faulkner’s “conflict in the human heart”, that Martin is inspired by. This fear isn’t simply because of Cat’s influence on Sansa growing up, but also because of what is happening between them as they feel like almost strangers getting to know one another.

What really grips me about Sackheim’s phrase “Fear of the unknown” on a psychological level for these two characters is that it reminds me the the concept of Unheimlich that Freud talks about in his essay “The Uncanny”. I know this might start appearing a bit too wordy, but bear with me. This is only a minute section in a larger series of posts. Just to clarify I don’t think the creators in question actually read the essay, but I think it does offer some insight within the field of aesthetics, that most people seem to innately understand without reflecting on the “why”. The themes of familiarity and unfamiliarity are a part of a huge body of literature, whether in a social, political or psychological sense.

As a disclaimer, I think Freud’s theories are heavily criticisable, especially on a scientific level and this is perhaps, one of the only essays that I think has worth because it’s more literary and taps into themes explored in fiction. In his essay, Freud talks about the closest explanation “uncanny” comes from the German word unheimlich, which is the opposite of the word heimlich that means “homely” or familiar. So unheimlich means “unhomely” and unfamiliar. He also writes that fear is a fundamental part of the “uncanny”. Many interpret this as “uncanny” or unheimlich to mean fear of the unfamiliar. That is how I felt Sackheim’s quote connects. Of course, it’s a lot more complicated than that because Jon and Sansa aren’t exactly strangers because they grew up in the same vicinity in Winterfell, but they were hardly involved in each other’s lives. They were part of an extended group of Starks but on the two polar opposite sides of the spectrum. Incidentally, Freud argues that the definition of the “uncanny” or unheimlich is not so concrete.

“In general we are reminded that the word ‘heimlich’ is not unambiguous, but belongs to two sets of ideas, which, without being contradictory, are yet very different: on the one hand it means what is familiar and agreeable, and on the other, what is concealed and kept out of sight. ‘Unheimlich’ is customarily used, we are told, as the contrary only of the first signification of ‘heimlich’, and not of the second. Sanders tells us nothing concerning a possible genetic connection between these two meanings of heimlich. On the other hand, we notice that Schelling says something which throws quite a new light on the concept of the Unheimlich, for which we were certainly not prepared. According to him, everything is unheimlich that ought to have remained secret and hidden but has come to light.” - “The Uncanny (1919), Freud

So essentially, the second understanding of “unheimlich” means something familiar and hidden that is revealed. In the case of the story in question, this concept is explored through Jon and Sansa’s inappropriate feelings for one another thinking of each other as half-siblings and his actual parentage that is hidden from them and the rest of the world. In a literary manner, the presence of these inappropriate attraction is them somewhere deep down knowing Jon is “not a Stark”, i.e. he isn’t Ned’s son, and scratching on the concealed truth. There is a certain irony to the idea that Jon wonders why he is having these inappropriate Targaryen-like incestuous feelings and the truth being that he is in fact Targaryen. In literature, authors can explore a number of things that may not work in real life, like this gut feeling of infringing on some prohibited territory that would reveal the lie around which Jon’s life has been wrapped around.

The fact that the show revealed Jon’s parentage in the same episode where it seemed to frame his scenes with Sansa quite romantically, adds to this reading. The characters are unaware of it, but as viewers there is some, if not complete, relief offered for noticing this odd framing of two characters belonging to the House with a reputation of being too honourable. One may brush this off because Jon and Dany’s relationship in season 7. But this piece of information is heavily implied a whole season before they actually meet and commit accidental incest, which is another literary trope that follows punishment. There is also a kind of irony in the fact that Jon distances himself from Sansa to avoid committing incest, and because of his lack of knowledge on his parentage commits it anyway. In the larger scheme of things, his feelings for Sansa as a cousin would not be considered wrong in Westeros and many a match were made around cousin marriages.

Of course, the show doesn’t explicitly acknowledge it and the crew remains silent on it even more than the cast, which is unsure at best and otherwise describing this tension as “sibling rivalry”. But as I pointed out in my last post, it’s not about the actors’ chemistry. It’s about their cinematic framing that uses visual romantic subtext, the methodology of which trinuviel and bitchcakegreen have talked about in their posts. It requires a large number of people involved to actually deliver this result so a lot of people, including directors of completely different episodes, were required to maintain this consistency. It’s not only shippers who noted this, but a number of reviewers who didn’t exactly want it to happen and were confused by the “framing” and the “way it was shot”.

“I definitely think they’re building some sort of romantic something between the two, and I’m not sure where any of it is supposed to be headed. But it’s definitely strange! (In particular, they seem to be deliberately framing the two as roughly analogous to Ned and Cat.)” - Todd VanDerWerff in response to his comments on his 6x10 review.

The show seems to make them visually nod to a number of positive romantic dynamics like Ned/Cat, Jaime/Brienne, Sam/Gilly, Robb/Talisa, and even a bit of Greyworm/Missandei. Many of these are noted by reviewers. That’s a lot of romantic dynamics to visually echo if you want this relationship to be read as platonic. If that wasn’t enough, one of the oddest things is that in the last episode where Jon and Sansa shared scenes together, the show nodded to not only Ned’s choke-hold of Littlefinger over Cat in season 1, but also Jaime and Brienne’s season 6 goodbye. Mark Mylod who was the director episode 7x02, also directed episode 6x08, where Jaime and Brienne had their goodbye scene. That’s alluding to two romantic dynamics in two back-to-back scenes, while the characters’ intentions behind certain actions are left ambiguous. It’s subtle, like the quiet chemistry involved in couples framed to be in the initial stages of courtship in period dramas. There is teasing banter and shows of affection, but there is also a hesitation and holding back in these moments apart from those that involve arguments. 

This continues with Jon’s odd reactions to Sansa’s “suitors” mentioning her, the goodbye scene at Dragonstone where Jorah looks back at Dany while Jon doesn’t, their confusing titles as Jon is KITN but not Lord of Winterfell as Sansa is Lady (and acting Lord) of Winterfell because of her claim, the use of the Lord’s chambers as a narrative device, and people questioning the nature of Sansa’s feelings towards Jon assuming her hesitation to be about power rather than something else. Somehow, because of the other dynamics coming into the fold while Jon and Sansa are distanced, their moments of connection are spelt out even more. Jon and Sansa argued and kept things from each other, but ultimately they still had conversations where they cleared the air and also let down their guard a little. They allowed themselves a few moments of vulnerability and offering each other validation despite their disagreements. This did not happen with Sansa and Arya, who had more of a relationship growing up than Jon and Sansa.  

A number of people’s reactions come with the descriptors “strange” and “weird” and a hesitation to completely believe. The fact that it comes off strange may be deliberate as the characters never really act on anything or acknowledge this romantic tension and the audience is left hanging. It leaves one with a feeling of unease because one doesn’t know what to expect and if it is truly happening. It’s kind of a continuation of Sackheim’s “stringing along the anticipation […] as long as possible to create a feeling of longing” which is built around that tentativeness of their actions. Even when it is pushed to the background. Four directors after Sackheim carry on this tension, where they share scenes (and more if you count related scenes). There is a “je ne sais quoi”, an indefinable, intrinsic feeling to it all. The trained viewer, who has consumed a lot of visual-audio content, can see it - even if they don’t want to - because of internalising the language of film. Even the argument about it as having no basis in books is very contestable. 

The result is that as much as the characters do not know what to expect, the audience doesn’t either. So, it is easier to fall into the alternative explanation that the narrative acknowledges in the text even when it doesn’t answer everything about the subtext. Certain actions may be dismissed as a coincidence, but it starts feeling more strange when the occurences keep building and even make narrative (and political) sense. Therefore, not only are the characters made to undergo this “uncanny” experience so is the audience made to, even when they know the truth about Jon’s parentage and how it could change everything that one assumed about the story before. It crosses the boundary of shipping this dynamic to become about people deep down needing to know if they were right about what the show was telling them via framing. It’s the same kind of relief that people who thought episode 6x10 undoubtedly framed them romantically felt after Jon’s parentage reveal later in the episode. 

I cannot know the ending of the story, of course, but I’ve said multiple times that season 7 didn’t end possibilities. Rather made it more of an inevitable political requirement should he survive. Politics, as loosely as D&D follow it, is at the crux of the story. Everything stands because of the end goal is headed. As much as I’d like to go into scene break-downs already, because Jon and Dany have occurred in the story, it is difficult to avoid discussing their very own framing. In the next post, I will talk about the visual juxtaposition of Jon/Dany and Jon/Sansa within the same season as they share two directors for different episodes.

(to be continued…)

Part 3

It requires a large number of people involved to actually deliver this result so a lot of people, including directors of completely different episodes, were required to maintain this consistency. It’s not only shippers who noted this, but a number of reviewers who didn’t exactly want it to happen and were confused by the “framing” and the “way it was shot”.

“I definitely think they’re building some sort of romantic something between the two, and I’m not sure where any of it is supposed to be headed. But it’s definitely strange! (In particular, they seem to be deliberately framing the two as roughly analogous to Ned and Cat.)” - Todd VanDerWerff in response to his comments on his 6x10 review.

The show seems to make them visually nod to a number of positive romantic dynamics like Ned/Cat, Jaime/Brienne, Sam/Gilly, Robb/Talisa, and even a bit of Greyworm/Missandei. Many of these are noted by reviewers. That’s a lot of romantic dynamics to visually echo if you want this relationship to be read as platonic. If that wasn’t enough, one of the oddest things is that in the last episode where Jon and Sansa shared scenes together, the show nodded to not only Ned’s choke-hold of Littlefinger over Cat in season 1, but also Jaime and Brienne’s season 6 goodbye. Mark Mylod who was the director episode 7x02, also directed episode 6x08, where Jaime and Brienne had their goodbye scene. That’s alluding to two romantic dynamics in two back-to-back scenes, while the characters’ intentions behind certain actions are left ambiguous. It’s subtle, like the quiet chemistry involved in couples framed to be in the initial stages of courtship in period dramas. There is teasing banter and shows of affection, but there is also a hesitation and holding back in these moments apart from those that involve arguments. 

This continues with Jon’s odd reactions to Sansa’s “suitors” mentioning her, the goodbye scene at Dragonstone where Jorah looks back at Dany while Jon doesn’t, their confusing titles as Jon is KITN but not Lord of Winterfell as Sansa is Lady (and acting Lord) of Winterfell because of her claim, the use of the Lord’s chambers as a narrative device, and people questioning the nature of Sansa’s feelings towards Jon assuming her hesitation to be about power rather than something else. Somehow, because of the other dynamics coming into the fold while Jon and Sansa are distanced, their moments of connection are spelt out even more. Jon and Sansa argued and kept things from each other, but ultimately they still had conversations where they cleared the air and also let down their guard a little. They allowed themselves a few moments of vulnerability and offering each other validation despite their disagreements. This did not happen with Sansa and Arya, who had more of a relationship growing up than Jon and Sansa.  

A number of people’s reactions come with the descriptors “strange” and “weird” and a hesitation to completely believe. The fact that it comes off strange may be deliberate as the characters never really act on anything or acknowledge this romantic tension and the audience is left hanging. It leaves one with a feeling of unease because one doesn’t know what to expect and if it is truly happening. It’s kind of a continuation of Sackheim’s “stringing along the anticipation […] as long as possible to create a feeling of longing” which is built around that tentativeness of their actions. Even when it is pushed to the background. Four directors after Sackheim carry on this tension, where they share scenes (and more if you count related scenes). There is a “je ne sais quoi”, an indefinable, intrinsic feeling to it all. The trained viewer, who has consumed a lot of visual-audio content, can see it - even if they don’t want to - because of internalising the language of film. Even the argument about it as having no basis in books is very contestable. 

The result is that as much as the characters do not know what to expect, the audience doesn’t either. So, it is easier to fall into the alternative explanation that the narrative acknowledges in the text even when it doesn’t answer everything about the subtext. Certain actions may be dismissed as a coincidence, but it starts feeling more strange when the occurences keep building and even make narrative (and political) sense. Therefore, not only are the characters made to undergo this “uncanny” experience so is the audience made to, even when they know the truth about Jon’s parentage and how it could change everything that one assumed about the story before. It crosses the boundary of shipping this dynamic to become about people deep down needing to know if they were right about what the show was telling them via framing. It’s the same kind of relief that people who thought episode 6x10 undoubtedly framed them romantically felt after Jon’s parentage reveal later in the episode. 

I cannot know the ending of the story, of course, but I’ve said multiple times that season 7 didn’t end possibilities. Rather made it more of an inevitable political requirement should he survive. Politics, as loosely as D&D follow it, is at the crux of the story. Everything stands because of the end goal is headed. As much as I’d like to go into scene break-downs already, because Jon and Dany have occurred in the story, it is difficult to avoid discussing their very own framing. In the next post, I will talk about the visual juxtaposition of Jon/Dany and Jon/Sansa within the same season as they share two directors for different episodes.

(to be continued…)

Part 3
trail.content:
As I brought up in my previous post,  a lot of the time when people talk about Jon and Sansa’s dynamic on the show, they don’t really reflect on why that “tension” exists as much or what it’s really about. The characters keep shifting between arguing and bickering to letting down their guard for a bit and being vulnerable around each other. But there’s always something left unsaid. Something that isn’t acknowledged. This unlabelled “something” is a number of issues related to their individual journeys, the perception of them, but also, as I noted in Part 1, it comes down to romantic framing of that tension as well using cinematic devices that goes far beyond actors’ chemistry.

The way this dynamic is framed narratively, the personal is political and the political is personal. The ‘otherness’ that doesn’t exist in Jon and Arya’s dynamic exists in Jon and Sansa’s.  It’s a very confusing dynamic to a person who wants to establish them as “complete enemies” or just “sibling rivalry” (as they don’t know they’re cousins) because they never completely settle into that. Their biggest theme being ‘trust each other’, not because they do completely, but because they want to and struggle to be able to. In a way, it all comes back to the 7x01 script note “They skirt around the true tension between them; all is subtext.”

“Maybe it’s the late second act complication that gives way to ~~~love~~~~~.( I am amused by how the show seems to vacillate wildly between [Jon and Sansa] being secretly in love and secretly enemies.)” - Todd VanDerWerff in his responses to a comment on his 6x10 review

Although I had said last time that I will be getting into discussing the characters’ individual after providing the context of cinematic framing, I will be stalling that for another post it seems. This post elaborates on the way Jon and Sansa are shot creates both visual romantic tension, but also narrative tension, and how that plays a role in storytelling.

The Tension between the Familiar and the Unfamiliar 

As you see from Todd VanDerWerff’s quote above, he describes them with two polar opposites, secretly in love and secretly enemies, that it oscillates “wildly” between. It’s a tension of opposites. “Tuesdays with Morrie” seems relevant to quote here. As I go through this series while delving into more character motivations in scenes, this quote will become more relevant to explain why Jon and Sansa react the way they do.

“The tension of opposites: Life is a series of pulls back and forth. You want to do one thing, but you are bound to do something else. Something hurts you, yet you know it shouldn’t. You take certain things for granted, even when you know you should never take anything for granted. A tension of opposites, like a pull on a rubber band. And most of us live somewhere in the middle.” - Tuesdays with Morrie by Mitch Albom

Because of these two polar opposite descriptors “secretly in love” and “secretly enemies”, it creates a push and pull to their dynamic, which doesn’t allow it to settle into a stable sibling-like dynamic that they want to settle into, despite never having it. It creates the feeling of the trope of “Will They or Won’t They?” where even their arguments feel like Belligerent Sexual Tension or Like An Old Married Couple because of the way they are shot.

“Sansa and Jon proceed to get into a very old-married-couple fight.” - Rachel Handler, MTV 6x09 review

“With all their bickering, one almost wonders if [Jon and Sansa] are a few episodes away from getting down together.” - Bennett Madison, Vanity Fair episode 7x01 review

“So Jon and Sansa…they’re like cousins right? […] I think they’re going to end up together” “Maybe I’m just crazy but I’m feeling vibes and that makes me feel better because I felt like they were pushing that” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x01 Podcast

“I said this last episode. They’re creating this weird tension between Jon and Sansa and we know he’s not her brother” “Yeah they’re cousins” - Cast of Thrones, Episode 7x02 podcast

But it does go a lot deeper than that because it comes down to the underlying emotions and unfamiliarity between these characters despite growing up in Winterfell together. It’s more “known” to them to not connect with each other or trust each other (and definitely not be attracted to each other). So a lot of the fighting personal insecurities aside, is about wanting a sense of going back to what they know because the entire situation feels too strange. To understand the root of this tension between Jon and Sansa, one has to go back to the very first scene of them that we see on screen. Their reunion.

“The characters had not seen each other for a number of years (six seasons) and so what we discussed was that it should seem almost dream like to them, and that there would be some tentativeness to their actions. It was about stringing along the anticipation of the reunion as long as possible to create the feeling of longing and so that the moment they hugged would feel earned and satisfying.” - Sackheim, Reddit Q&A

Of the reunions so far, it was the most emotionally rewarding despite being the most distant growing up and despite the underlying conflict between them that comes up afterward. The “almost dream-like” effect that Sackheim talks about shows in their reunion more than others. As Jon and Sansa still upon seeing each other, and hold eyes only on each other as Jon slowly makes his way to her and stands in front of her, still staring, unable to believe she is there. As Bran has been subsumed under the Three Eyed Raven, he is emotionally absent and anyway, Sansa breaks her disbelief with Bran much faster than she did with Jon in episode 6x04. Later, Arya comes to Winterfell with expectations of seeing Jon, who she was closest to, and finds Sansa, who she had a strained relationship, instead. Arya is met with a bit of disappointment because she had expectations. Thus, it is a bit - if not completely - underwhelming because it’s visible that it is underwhelming to Arya.

“The idea that after all Jon and Sansa have been through as characters, they’re finally able to put a foot back on solid ground in terms of family and with whom that runs deeper than any other bond. It was a big moment for them and for us to see it” “And to knowing where two of them are going to go with their relationship that never really meant that much before but now means so much more because at this point, they’re all that they have.” - D&D, Inside the Episode

Jon and Sansa, on the other hand, because of never being close and being the first of the pack to reunite, didn’t have any such high expectations. After the journeys they went through, anything from each other felt like an oasis in a desert. They fall into a strange ease and comfort, a quiet solace with moments of banter, but they also resist it. Sackheim brings up two conflicting emotions that their reunion was meant to capture: joy and fear, where the fear is overpowering and holds them back.

“The only note I gave them during the scene was, “Hold yourself back. As much as it’s joyous to see each other, you’re equally as scared. You don’t know what to expect.” The operative word was fear. Fear of the unknown. In a way, it added to the emotional resonance of the scene” - David Sackheim, director of 6x04 on Jon and Sansa’s reunion

Sackheim’s emphasis on that “tentativeness” and “fear of the unknown” in the scene is what builds tension in that scene before offering catharsis. While I do think that Jon and Arya’s reunion may still capture that “almost dream-like” effect, because of their close relationship growing up, there would be no fear. Currently where the story left off, they are aware of each other’s survival and hope to reunite at Winterfell so watching it happen might bring on the waterworks but so would it bring on pure unadulterated joy because they’ve probably imagined this a number of times. There would be familiarity and complete unfaltering trust in Jon and Arya’s dynamic. On the other hand, as glad as Jon and Sansa are to find one another, their mutual “fear of the unknown” prevents them from ever completely falling into a sibling dynamic, even when they try to build bridges. In a way because of its two conflicting feelings of joy and fear, it encompasses Faulkner’s “conflict in the human heart”, that Martin is inspired by. This fear isn’t simply because of Cat’s influence on Sansa growing up, but also because of what is happening between them as they feel like almost strangers getting to know one another.

What really grips me about Sackheim’s phrase “Fear of the unknown” on a psychological level for these two characters is that it reminds me the the concept of Unheimlich that Freud talks about in his essay “The Uncanny”. I know this might start appearing a bit too wordy, but bear with me. This is only a minute section in a larger series of posts. Just to clarify I don’t think the creators in question actually read the essay, but I think it does offer some insight within the field of aesthetics, that most people seem to innately understand without reflecting on the “why”. The themes of familiarity and unfamiliarity are a part of a huge body of literature, whether in a social, political or psychological sense.

As a disclaimer, I think Freud’s theories are heavily criticisable, especially on a scientific level and this is perhaps, one of the only essays that I think has worth because it’s more literary and taps into themes explored in fiction. In his essay, Freud talks about the closest explanation “uncanny” comes from the German word unheimlich, which is the opposite of the word heimlich that means “homely” or familiar. So unheimlich means “unhomely” and unfamiliar. He also writes that fear is a fundamental part of the “uncanny”. Many interpret this as “uncanny” or unheimlich to mean fear of the unfamiliar. That is how I felt Sackheim’s quote connects. Of course, it’s a lot more complicated than that because Jon and Sansa aren’t exactly strangers because they grew up in the same vicinity in Winterfell, but they were hardly involved in each other’s lives. They were part of an extended group of Starks but on the two polar opposite sides of the spectrum. Incidentally, Freud argues that the definition of the “uncanny” or unheimlich is not so concrete.

“In general we are reminded that the word ‘heimlich’ is not unambiguous, but belongs to two sets of ideas, which, without being contradictory, are yet very different: on the one hand it means what is familiar and agreeable, and on the other, what is concealed and kept out of sight. ‘Unheimlich’ is customarily used, we are told, as the contrary only of the first signification of ‘heimlich’, and not of the second. Sanders tells us nothing concerning a possible genetic connection between these two meanings of heimlich. On the other hand, we notice that Schelling says something which throws quite a new light on the concept of the Unheimlich, for which we were certainly not prepared. According to him, everything is unheimlich that ought to have remained secret and hidden but has come to light.” - “The Uncanny (1919), Freud

So essentially, the second understanding of “unheimlich” means something familiar and hidden that is revealed. In the case of the story in question, this concept is explored through Jon and Sansa’s inappropriate feelings for one another thinking of each other as half-siblings and his actual parentage that is hidden from them and the rest of the world. In a literary manner, the presence of these inappropriate attraction is them somewhere deep down knowing Jon is “not a Stark”, i.e. he isn’t Ned’s son, and scratching on the concealed truth. There is a certain irony to the idea that Jon wonders why he is having these inappropriate Targaryen-like incestuous feelings and the truth being that he is in fact Targaryen. In literature, authors can explore a number of things that may not work in real life, like this gut feeling of infringing on some prohibited territory that would reveal the lie around which Jon’s life has been wrapped around.

The fact that the show revealed Jon’s parentage in the same episode where it seemed to frame his scenes with Sansa quite romantically, adds to this reading. The characters are unaware of it, but as viewers there is some, if not complete, relief offered for noticing this odd framing of two characters belonging to the House with a reputation of being too honourable. One may brush this off because Jon and Dany’s relationship in season 7. But this piece of information is heavily implied a whole season before they actually meet and commit accidental incest, which is another literary trope that follows punishment. There is also a kind of irony in the fact that Jon distances himself from Sansa to avoid committing incest, and because of his lack of knowledge on his parentage commits it anyway. In the larger scheme of things, his feelings for Sansa as a cousin would not be considered wrong in Westeros and many a match were made around cousin marriages.

Of course, the show doesn’t explicitly acknowledge it and the crew remains silent on it even more than the cast, which is unsure at best and otherwise describing this tension as “sibling rivalry”. But as I pointed out in my last post, it’s not about the actors’ chemistry. It’s about their cinematic framing that uses visual romantic subtext, the methodology of which trinuviel and bitchcakegreen have talked about in their posts. blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: I was watching some Jon/Dany vids on youtube and found some really nice ones. This one stuck out - beautifully made and...
caption: I was watching some Jon/Dany vids on youtube and found some really nice ones. This one stuck out - beautifully made and wonderfully illustrating why these characters fell in love. They have so much in common - a need to help people, an inner strength that helps them survive the odds as the last Targaryens at the ends of the world slowly rising up as the other houses destroy each other, magical prophecies and pets, earning loyalty through their actions and taking risks by fighting at the head of their armies. Whether they live or die next season, I am sure they will be at each other’s side fighting together for Westeros and for each other. As the show emphasized last season: Together. A Song of Ice and Fire indeed.
